text: Diabetes mellitus is a group of metabolic diseases characterized by chronic hyperglycemia resulting from defects in insulin secretion, insulin action, or both. The chronic hyperglycemia of diabetes is associated with long-term damage, dysfunction, and failure of various organs, especially the eyes, kidneys, nerves, heart, and blood vessels. Type 1 diabetes results from autoimmune destruction of the beta cells of the pancreas, leading to absolute insulin deficiency. Type 2 diabetes, which accounts for approximately 90-95% of all cases, results from a progressive insulin secretory defect on the background of insulin resistance.

The cardiovascular system consists of the heart, blood vessels, and blood. The heart is a muscular organ that pumps blood throughout the body through a network of arteries and veins. The right side of the heart receives deoxygenated blood from the body and pumps it to the lungs for oxygenation. The left side receives oxygenated blood from the lungs and pumps it to the rest of the body. Coronary arteries supply the heart muscle itself with oxygen and nutrients. Atherosclerosis, the buildup of fatty plaques in arterial walls, is the primary cause of coronary artery disease and myocardial infarction.

Hypertension, or high blood pressure, is defined as a systolic blood pressure of 130 mmHg or higher or a diastolic blood pressure of 80 mmHg or higher. Primary hypertension, which accounts for 90-95% of cases, has no identifiable cause but is associated with genetic factors, obesity, high sodium intake, physical inactivity, and excessive alcohol consumption. Secondary hypertension results from underlying conditions such as renal disease, endocrine disorders, or medication effects. Uncontrolled hypertension significantly increases the risk of stroke, heart failure, coronary artery disease, chronic kidney disease, and peripheral vascular disease.

The respiratory system facilitates gas exchange between the body and the environment. Air enters through the nasal passages or mouth, travels through the pharynx, larynx, and trachea, then branches into the bronchi and bronchioles before reaching the alveoli. The alveoli are tiny air sacs surrounded by capillaries where oxygen diffuses into the blood and carbon dioxide diffuses out. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease encompasses emphysema and chronic bronchitis, characterized by airflow limitation that is not fully reversible. The primary cause is cigarette smoking, with occupational exposures and genetic factors also contributing.

The immune system protects the body against pathogens through innate and adaptive immunity. Innate immunity provides immediate, non-specific defense through physical barriers, phagocytic cells, natural killer cells, and inflammatory responses. Adaptive immunity develops over time and provides specific, long-lasting protection through T lymphocytes and B lymphocytes. T cells coordinate immune responses and directly kill infected cells, while B cells produce antibodies that neutralize pathogens. Autoimmune diseases occur when the immune system mistakenly attacks the body's own tissues, as seen in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, and type 1 diabetes.

The nervous system is divided into the central nervous system, comprising the brain and spinal cord, and the peripheral nervous system, consisting of cranial and spinal nerves. Neurons are the functional units, transmitting electrical signals called action potentials. Neurotransmitters facilitate communication between neurons at synapses. The brain contains approximately 86 billion neurons and is organized into regions with specialized functions. The cerebral cortex handles higher cognitive functions, the cerebellum coordinates movement, the brainstem controls vital functions, and the limbic system processes emotions and memory.

The gastrointestinal tract extends from the mouth to the anus and is responsible for digestion, absorption, and elimination. Mechanical and chemical digestion begins in the mouth with mastication and salivary enzymes. The stomach produces hydrochloric acid and pepsin for protein digestion. The small intestine, the primary site of nutrient absorption, is lined with villi and microvilli to maximize surface area. The large intestine absorbs water and electrolytes while harboring beneficial bacteria. The liver produces bile for fat emulsification and metabolizes absorbed nutrients. The pancreas secretes digestive enzymes and bicarbonate.

Pharmacokinetics describes how the body processes drugs through absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion. Absorption depends on the route of administration, drug formulation, and physiological factors. Distribution is influenced by blood flow, tissue permeability, plasma protein binding, and lipid solubility. The liver is the primary site of drug metabolism, with cytochrome P450 enzymes playing a central role. Renal excretion is the main route of drug elimination, though biliary excretion and pulmonary elimination also occur. Drug interactions can alter pharmacokinetics through enzyme induction or inhibition, affecting therapeutic efficacy and toxicity.

Cancer develops when cells acquire genetic mutations that enable uncontrolled proliferation, resistance to cell death, and ability to invade surrounding tissues and metastasize. Carcinogenesis is a multistep process involving initiation, promotion, and progression. Oncogenes drive cell growth when activated, while tumor suppressor genes normally inhibit proliferation. The hallmarks of cancer include sustained proliferative signaling, evasion of growth suppressors, resistance to cell death, replicative immortality, angiogenesis, invasion and metastasis, reprogrammed energy metabolism, and immune evasion. Treatment modalities include surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, targeted therapy, and immunotherapy.

The endocrine system consists of glands that produce hormones regulating metabolism, growth, development, reproduction, and homeostasis. The hypothalamus links the nervous and endocrine systems, controlling the pituitary gland. The pituitary secretes hormones that regulate other endocrine glands including the thyroid, adrenal glands, and gonads. Thyroid hormones control metabolic rate. The adrenal cortex produces cortisol and aldosterone, while the medulla secretes epinephrine and norepinephrine. The pancreatic islets produce insulin and glucagon for glucose homeostasis. Hormone disorders result from excess, deficiency, or resistance.

The musculoskeletal system provides structural support, enables movement, and protects vital organs. The human skeleton contains 206 bones that undergo constant remodeling through osteoblast bone formation and osteoclast resorption. Joints are classified as synovial, cartilaginous, or fibrous based on structure. Skeletal muscles attach to bones via tendons and contract through actin-myosin interactions powered by ATP hydrolysis. Osteoarthritis involves cartilage degeneration in weight-bearing joints, while rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disease causing synovial inflammation. Osteoporosis results from decreased bone density, increasing fracture risk.

The renal system maintains fluid and electrolyte balance, excretes metabolic waste, and regulates blood pressure. Each kidney contains approximately one million nephrons, the functional units consisting of glomeruli and tubules. Glomerular filtration produces about 180 liters of filtrate daily, which is modified by tubular reabsorption and secretion to produce 1-2 liters of urine. The kidneys regulate acid-base balance through bicarbonate reabsorption and hydrogen ion secretion. Erythropoietin production stimulates red blood cell formation, while vitamin D activation supports calcium homeostasis. Chronic kidney disease progression is staged by glomerular filtration rate.

Hematology encompasses the study of blood and blood-forming organs. Blood consists of plasma and cellular elements including erythrocytes, leukocytes, and platelets. Erythrocytes transport oxygen bound to hemoglobin and carbon dioxide as bicarbonate. Leukocytes include neutrophils, lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils, and basophils, each with distinct immune functions. Platelets initiate hemostasis through adhesion, activation, and aggregation. Coagulation involves a cascade of clotting factors culminating in fibrin formation. Anemias are classified by erythrocyte size and hemoglobin content, with causes ranging from iron deficiency to hemolysis to bone marrow failure.

Infectious diseases result from pathogenic microorganisms including bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites. Transmission occurs through respiratory droplets, fecal-oral routes, blood-borne contact, vector-borne spread, or direct contact. The host immune response determines disease outcome, with factors including pathogen virulence, inoculum size, and host immunity. Antibiotic resistance develops through genetic mutations and horizontal gene transfer, driven by antimicrobial overuse. Vaccination provides active immunity by exposing the immune system to antigens without causing disease. Epidemiology studies disease distribution and determinants to inform public health interventions.

Psychiatry addresses mental disorders affecting cognition, emotion, and behavior. Major depressive disorder is characterized by persistent depressed mood, anhedonia, sleep and appetite changes, fatigue, worthlessness, and suicidal ideation. Bipolar disorder involves episodes of mania and depression. Anxiety disorders include generalized anxiety, panic disorder, social anxiety, and specific phobias. Schizophrenia presents with positive symptoms like hallucinations and delusions, negative symptoms like flat affect, and cognitive impairment. Neurotransmitter imbalances, genetic factors, and environmental stressors contribute to pathophysiology. Treatment includes pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy.

Dermatology focuses on conditions affecting the skin, hair, nails, and mucous membranes. The skin consists of epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue, serving as a barrier against pathogens, regulating temperature, and mediating sensation. Common conditions include eczema, characterized by itchy, inflamed skin; psoriasis, an autoimmune condition causing scaly plaques; acne, resulting from follicular obstruction and inflammation; and skin cancers including basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma. Diagnosis often relies on clinical examination, dermoscopy, and histopathological analysis of biopsies.

Ophthalmology deals with eye disorders and visual function. The eye refracts light through the cornea and lens to focus images on the retina, where photoreceptors convert light to neural signals transmitted via the optic nerve to the brain. Refractive errors include myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism. Cataracts involve lens opacification causing visual impairment. Glaucoma results from optic nerve damage typically associated with elevated intraocular pressure. Age-related macular degeneration affects central vision. Diabetic retinopathy is a microvascular complication of diabetes causing vision loss through retinal changes.

Obstetrics and gynecology encompasses reproductive health, pregnancy, and childbirth. The menstrual cycle involves follicular development, ovulation, and endometrial preparation under hormonal control. Pregnancy lasts approximately 40 weeks from the last menstrual period, divided into trimesters with distinct developmental milestones. Prenatal care monitors maternal and fetal health, screening for complications like preeclampsia, gestational diabetes, and fetal anomalies. Labor progresses through cervical dilation, fetal descent, and delivery. Common gynecologic conditions include endometriosis, polycystic ovary syndrome, uterine fibroids, and cervical dysplasia.

Pediatrics focuses on the health of infants, children, and adolescents through physical, emotional, and social development. Growth parameters including weight, length, and head circumference are monitored against standardized curves. Developmental milestones in motor, language, cognitive, and social domains help identify delays requiring intervention. Immunizations protect against vaccine-preventable diseases according to recommended schedules. Common childhood illnesses include respiratory infections, otitis media, gastroenteritis, and rashes. Chronic conditions like asthma, diabetes, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder require ongoing management with considerations for growth and development.

Geriatric medicine addresses the complex health needs of older adults, recognizing physiological changes of aging and increased prevalence of multimorbidity, polypharmacy, and functional impairment. Geriatric syndromes including frailty, falls, cognitive impairment, incontinence, and sensory decline require comprehensive assessment. Delirium, an acute confusional state, is common in hospitalized elderly and often indicates underlying illness. Dementia involves progressive cognitive decline affecting daily function, with Alzheimer disease being most common. Care goals often emphasize function preservation, symptom management, and quality of life alongside disease treatment.

Emergency medicine involves immediate diagnosis and treatment of acute illnesses and injuries. Triage systems prioritize patients based on severity. Resuscitation follows structured protocols for airway management, breathing support, circulation restoration, and disability assessment. Common presentations include chest pain, dyspnea, abdominal pain, trauma, and altered mental status. Time-sensitive conditions like myocardial infarction, stroke, sepsis, and trauma require rapid recognition and protocol-driven management. Emergency physicians coordinate multidisciplinary care and make disposition decisions regarding admission, observation, or discharge.

Surgery encompasses operative treatment of diseases, injuries, and deformities. Preoperative assessment evaluates surgical risk and optimizes medical conditions. Anesthesia provides unconsciousness, amnesia, analgesia, and muscle relaxation for procedures. Surgical approaches include open, laparoscopic, and robotic techniques. Postoperative care addresses pain management, wound healing, thromboprophylaxis, and complication surveillance. General surgery addresses abdominal conditions; orthopedic surgery treats musculoskeletal disorders; cardiovascular surgery manages heart and vessel diseases; neurosurgery addresses central and peripheral nervous system conditions. Minimally invasive approaches reduce morbidity and recovery time.

Radiology utilizes imaging technology for diagnosis and image-guided intervention. X-rays visualize dense structures like bones and detect lung pathology. Computed tomography provides cross-sectional images using X-ray attenuation, excellent for trauma, malignancy, and vascular imaging. Magnetic resonance imaging uses radiofrequency pulses in magnetic fields, providing superior soft tissue contrast without ionizing radiation. Ultrasound uses sound waves for real-time imaging, particularly useful for abdominal, cardiac, obstetric, and vascular evaluation. Interventional radiology performs minimally invasive procedures using image guidance, including biopsies, drainages, and vascular interventions.

Pathology provides the foundation for disease diagnosis through examination of tissues, cells, and body fluids. Histopathology analyzes tissue architecture and cellular morphology from biopsies and surgical specimens. Cytopathology examines individual cells from aspirates, smears, and body fluids. Clinical pathology encompasses laboratory medicine including clinical chemistry, hematology, microbiology, and immunology. Molecular pathology detects genetic alterations for diagnosis, prognosis, and therapy selection. Autopsy determines cause of death and contributes to medical education and quality assurance. Pathologists integrate findings with clinical information to guide patient management.

Clinical pharmacology studies drug effects in humans to optimize therapeutic outcomes. Pharmacodynamics describes drug-receptor interactions and dose-response relationships. Therapeutic drug monitoring measures drug concentrations to maintain efficacy while minimizing toxicity. Drug development progresses through preclinical studies and phased clinical trials assessing safety, efficacy, and dosing. Adverse drug reactions range from predictable dose-dependent effects to unpredictable idiosyncratic reactions. Drug interactions occur through pharmacokinetic mechanisms affecting drug levels or pharmacodynamic mechanisms affecting drug effects. Rational prescribing considers indication, contraindications, patient factors, and cost-effectiveness.

Epidemiology is the study of disease distribution and determinants in populations. Descriptive epidemiology characterizes disease by person, place, and time. Analytical epidemiology tests hypotheses about disease etiology using observational designs including cohort, case-control, and cross-sectional studies. Experimental epidemiology evaluates interventions through randomized controlled trials. Key measures include incidence, prevalence, relative risk, odds ratio, and attributable risk. Screening programs detect disease in asymptomatic individuals, requiring tests with appropriate sensitivity and specificity. Evidence synthesis through systematic reviews and meta-analyses informs clinical guidelines and health policy.

Public health focuses on protecting and improving community health through organized efforts. Core functions include assessment of health status, policy development, and assurance of service availability. Health promotion encourages healthy behaviors through education and environmental changes. Disease prevention operates at primary level preventing disease onset, secondary level detecting early disease, and tertiary level minimizing disability. Vaccination programs, sanitation, food safety, and occupational health exemplify public health interventions. Health disparities reflect unequal disease burden across populations, requiring targeted interventions addressing social determinants of health.

Medical ethics provides frameworks for navigating moral issues in healthcare. Core principles include autonomy respecting patient self-determination, beneficence promoting patient welfare, non-maleficence avoiding harm, and justice ensuring fair resource distribution. Informed consent requires disclosure, comprehension, voluntariness, and competence. Confidentiality protects patient privacy while permitting exceptions for public safety. End-of-life ethics address treatment withdrawal, advance directives, and palliative care. Research ethics protect human subjects through institutional review, informed consent, and risk-benefit assessment. Ethical dilemmas require careful analysis weighing competing values and stakeholder perspectives.

Medical genetics studies the role of heredity in health and disease. Mendelian disorders follow single-gene inheritance patterns including autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, and X-linked. Chromosomal disorders involve numerical or structural abnormalities detectable by karyotyping. Complex disorders result from interactions between multiple genes and environmental factors. Genetic testing identifies mutations for diagnosis, carrier detection, and predictive testing. Genetic counseling helps individuals understand risks and make informed decisions. Pharmacogenomics applies genetic information to drug selection and dosing. Gene therapy and genome editing offer therapeutic potential for genetic diseases.

Medical education prepares physicians through undergraduate medical training, graduate medical education, and continuing professional development. Medical school curricula integrate basic sciences with clinical skills, emphasizing competency-based outcomes. Clinical rotations provide supervised patient care experience across specialties. Residency training provides specialty-specific expertise under graduated responsibility. Fellowship offers subspecialty training for additional expertise. Board certification validates specialty competence through examination. Continuing medical education maintains knowledge currency. Simulation, standardized patients, and e-learning complement traditional teaching methods. Assessment includes knowledge testing, clinical skills evaluation, and workplace-based observation.

Evidence-based medicine integrates best available research evidence with clinical expertise and patient values in clinical decision-making. The evidence hierarchy ranks study designs by methodological rigor, with randomized controlled trials and systematic reviews providing strongest evidence. Critical appraisal skills evaluate study validity, results, and applicability. Clinical practice guidelines synthesize evidence into recommendations. Point-of-care resources provide rapid access to evidence summaries. Implementation science addresses barriers to evidence adoption. Quality improvement methodology applies evidence to enhance care processes and outcomes. Shared decision-making involves patients in applying evidence to their individual circumstances.

Patient safety focuses on preventing harm during healthcare delivery. Adverse events result from medical errors rather than underlying disease. Systems thinking recognizes that errors often reflect system failures rather than individual negligence. Safety culture encourages error reporting without blame, enabling organizational learning. Root cause analysis investigates serious events to identify contributing factors. Standardization, checklists, and forcing functions reduce error likelihood. Communication failures contribute to many adverse events, addressed through structured handoffs and team training. Medication safety addresses prescribing, dispensing, administration, and monitoring errors. Patient engagement in safety includes verification processes and concern reporting.

Healthcare systems organize delivery, financing, and regulation of medical services. System components include primary care providing first-contact comprehensive care, secondary care offering specialist services, and tertiary care delivering advanced specialized treatment. Healthcare financing occurs through public funding, private insurance, or out-of-pocket payment. Access depends on availability, affordability, and acceptability of services. Quality measurement evaluates structure, process, and outcome indicators. Health information technology supports documentation, communication, and decision support. Healthcare reform addresses cost, quality, and access challenges through policy interventions. Comparative health systems analysis informs policy learning across nations.

Clinical reasoning is the cognitive process underlying diagnosis and management decisions. Pattern recognition enables rapid identification of classic presentations. Hypothetico-deductive reasoning generates and tests diagnostic hypotheses. Bayesian reasoning updates disease probability based on test results and prior probability. Cognitive biases including anchoring, availability, and confirmation bias can lead to diagnostic error. Metacognition involves monitoring and adjusting reasoning processes. Diagnostic uncertainty is inherent and requires tolerance while minimizing risk. Management decisions weigh benefits, harms, costs, and patient preferences. Clinical decision support systems assist reasoning through alerts, reminders, and recommendations.

Doctor-patient communication is fundamental to healthcare quality and outcomes. Effective communication improves diagnostic accuracy, treatment adherence, patient satisfaction, and health outcomes. Active listening demonstrates attention and understanding. Open-ended questions elicit patient perspectives. Empathy acknowledges emotional experiences. Health literacy considerations ensure information is understandable. Shared decision-making involves patients as partners in care choices. Motivational interviewing facilitates behavior change through exploring ambivalence. Breaking bad news requires preparation, empathy, and support. Cultural competence addresses diverse beliefs and practices. Communication skills can be taught, practiced, and assessed.

Nutrition science informs dietary recommendations for health promotion and disease management. Macronutrients including carbohydrates, proteins, and fats provide energy and structural components. Micronutrients including vitamins and minerals serve enzymatic and regulatory functions. Dietary patterns like Mediterranean and DASH diets associate with improved cardiovascular outcomes. Malnutrition encompasses undernutrition and overnutrition with obesity. Nutritional assessment evaluates dietary intake, anthropometry, and laboratory markers. Medical nutrition therapy addresses disease-specific dietary requirements. Enteral and parenteral nutrition support patients unable to meet needs orally. Food insecurity impacts health outcomes and requires social intervention.

Preventive medicine applies population and individual strategies to prevent disease and promote health. Primary prevention averts disease occurrence through vaccination, health education, and environmental modification. Secondary prevention detects disease early through screening programs targeting conditions meeting Wilson-Jungner criteria. Tertiary prevention minimizes disability and complications in those with established disease. Risk assessment identifies high-risk individuals for targeted intervention. Behavior change techniques address modifiable risk factors including tobacco, alcohol, physical inactivity, and diet. Chemoprevention uses medications to reduce disease risk in high-risk populations. Preventive care recommendations are evidence-based and periodically updated.

Rehabilitation medicine restores function and quality of life following illness or injury. The biopsychosocial model recognizes physical, psychological, and social dimensions of disability. Interdisciplinary teams include physiatrists, physical therapists, occupational therapists, speech therapists, psychologists, and social workers. Neurological rehabilitation addresses stroke, brain injury, and spinal cord injury. Musculoskeletal rehabilitation treats orthopedic conditions and amputations. Cardiac and pulmonary rehabilitation improve function in heart and lung disease. Prosthetics and orthotics substitute for or support body parts. Assistive technology enhances independence. Return to work and community integration are key outcomes.

Pain management addresses acute and chronic pain through multimodal approaches. Pain physiology involves nociception, transmission, modulation, and perception. Acute pain serves protective functions while chronic pain persists beyond healing and becomes disease itself. Assessment uses patient-reported scales, functional evaluation, and psychosocial screening. The WHO analgesic ladder guides pharmacological treatment escalation. Non-opioid analgesics include acetaminophen and NSAIDs. Opioids treat moderate to severe pain with careful attention to risk of dependence and adverse effects. Adjuvant medications address neuropathic pain. Interventional procedures include nerve blocks and spinal cord stimulation. Psychological approaches address cognitive and behavioral pain factors.

Palliative care provides relief from symptoms, pain, and stress of serious illness to improve quality of life for patients and families. Palliative care is appropriate at any illness stage alongside curative treatment. Symptom management addresses pain, dyspnea, nausea, fatigue, and psychological distress. Communication includes prognostic disclosure and goals of care discussions. Advance care planning documents patient preferences through advance directives. Hospice care focuses on comfort when curative treatment is no longer pursued. Interdisciplinary teams address physical, emotional, social, and spiritual needs. Bereavement support assists families after death. Early palliative care integration improves outcomes and may extend survival.

Global health addresses health issues transcending national boundaries and requiring international cooperation. The global burden of disease quantifies health loss from mortality and disability across conditions and regions. Communicable diseases including HIV, tuberculosis, malaria, and emerging infections remain major causes of death globally. Non-communicable diseases including cardiovascular disease, cancer, and diabetes increasingly affect low and middle income countries. Maternal and child health indicators reflect health system capacity. The Sustainable Development Goals establish health targets within broader development framework. International organizations coordinate global health governance. Health security addresses pandemic preparedness and response.

Clinical research generates evidence to improve patient care through systematic investigation. Study designs range from observational studies describing associations to randomized controlled trials testing interventions. Protocol development specifies research questions, methods, and analysis plans. Ethical review ensures research protects human subjects. Participant recruitment and consent obtain voluntary informed participation. Data collection follows standardized procedures to ensure quality. Statistical analysis tests hypotheses and quantifies effects. Peer review evaluates research quality before publication. Systematic reviews synthesize evidence across studies. Translational research bridges basic science discoveries and clinical application.

Medical informatics applies information science to healthcare. Electronic health records store patient information supporting care delivery, communication, and research. Clinical decision support systems provide alerts, reminders, and recommendations at the point of care. Health information exchange enables data sharing across organizations. Telehealth delivers care remotely through video, messaging, and remote monitoring. Artificial intelligence applications include image interpretation, natural language processing, and clinical prediction. Data analytics identify patterns for quality improvement and population health management. Interoperability standards enable system integration. Privacy and security protections safeguard sensitive health information.

Medical humanities explore the human dimensions of medicine through arts, literature, history, philosophy, and social sciences. Narrative medicine recognizes illness stories as central to understanding patient experience. Literature and cinema portray illness, dying, and healing. Medical history contextualizes current practice within evolution of medical knowledge and institutions. Philosophy of medicine examines concepts including disease, causation, and evidence. Sociology of medicine studies medical profession, medicalization, and illness behavior. Bioethics addresses moral questions arising from medical practice and research. Arts in medicine enhance patient wellbeing and provider resilience. Humanities education cultivates empathy, reflection, and cultural awareness.

The placebo effect demonstrates that therapeutic benefit can result from treatment context and patient expectations independent of specific pharmacological or physiological mechanisms. Placebo responses involve neurobiological pathways including endogenous opioids, dopamine, and cannabinoids. Factors enhancing placebo effects include positive expectations, conditioning, therapeutic relationship quality, and treatment ritual. Nocebo effects produce adverse outcomes from negative expectations. Ethical considerations arise regarding deception in clinical use. Placebo controls in clinical trials isolate intervention-specific effects. Understanding placebo mechanisms may enable their therapeutic optimization. The placebo response demonstrates mind-body interaction in healing.

Sleep medicine addresses disorders affecting sleep quality, timing, and adequacy. Normal sleep cycles through non-rapid eye movement and rapid eye movement stages serving restorative and cognitive functions. Insomnia involves difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep despite adequate opportunity. Obstructive sleep apnea causes repetitive upper airway collapse with oxygen desaturation and sleep fragmentation. Circadian rhythm disorders reflect misalignment between internal clock and environmental demands. Narcolepsy involves excessive daytime sleepiness with or without cataplexy. Restless legs syndrome causes uncomfortable leg sensations relieved by movement. Polysomnography objectively measures sleep parameters. Treatment ranges from cognitive behavioral therapy to positive airway pressure to pharmacotherapy depending on disorder.

Addiction medicine addresses substance use disorders and behavioral addictions. Addiction involves compulsive use despite harm, with neurobiological changes affecting reward, motivation, memory, and control circuits. Substances include alcohol, tobacco, opioids, stimulants, cannabis, and sedatives. Screening tools identify problematic use. Withdrawal management provides medical support during detoxification. Behavioral therapies including cognitive behavioral therapy, contingency management, and motivational enhancement address psychological factors. Medications for addiction treatment include naltrexone, buprenorphine, methadone for opioid use disorder and naltrexone, acamprosate, disulfiram for alcohol use disorder. Harm reduction strategies minimize consequences when abstinence is not achieved. Recovery support systems provide ongoing assistance.

Sports medicine addresses health issues related to exercise and athletic activity. Pre-participation examinations identify conditions affecting safe participation. Acute injuries include sprains, strains, fractures, and concussions requiring prompt diagnosis and appropriate management. Overuse injuries result from repetitive stress without adequate recovery. Rehabilitation restores function and prevents reinjury. Exercise prescription promotes health benefits while managing risks. Performance optimization addresses training, nutrition, and recovery. Special populations including youth, female athletes, and masters athletes have unique considerations. Doping and ergogenic aids raise ethical and health concerns. Team physicians coordinate care for athletic organizations.

Toxicology addresses the adverse effects of chemical, physical, and biological agents on living organisms. Drug overdose management follows a systematic approach: stabilize airway, breathing, and circulation; perform decontamination when appropriate; administer specific antidotes when available; and provide supportive care. Common antidotes include naloxone for opioids, flumazenil for benzodiazepines, N-acetylcysteine for acetaminophen, and chelation therapy for heavy metals. Poison control centers provide 24-hour consultation for complex cases.

Telemedicine has transformed healthcare delivery, enabling remote consultations, monitoring, and management. Virtual visits are appropriate for many conditions including chronic disease management, medication adjustments, mental health counseling, and follow-up appointments. Technology requirements include secure video platforms compliant with privacy regulations, reliable internet connectivity, and appropriate documentation systems. Limitations include inability to perform physical examination and potential technology barriers for some patients.
